>>631646183
Lich

Angel is the path with the most unique content and it's versatile enough to suit any build, although divine casters of course benefit the most thanks to merged spellbook
Demon is the path receiving the second most attention in terms of content, but I don't like said content (whether you're playing as a chaotic neutral pragmatist using demon powers for the benefit of the crusade, or an evil character, how the crusade transforms in Act 5 doesn't feel natural), and the powers while potent are very much tied to demonic rage that only lasts one combat encounter and has limited uses
Trickster is breaking-the-fourth-wall memes and I don't like the general concept on that count (although there are good individual moments where you get to unleash poetic justice and such), but I like the powers mechanically: rather than replacing the class toolkit, they are a lot more about simply boosting your extant powers (improved improved improved critical feats and the like), and they also boost companions substantially.

>>631648631
Okay, so let me break it down for you. Like seriously.

If your character is melee you really want stuff that gives you: +Hit (as in chance to hit), +Crit, and +Attacks. Look for that stuff. Weapon specialization, two weapon fighting, teamwork feats like outflank and seize the moment, improved critical feats. I know that sounds like a word salad but seriously just remember that: HIT. CRIT. ATTACKS.

Damage and Defenses are good too, by the way, and if there are not good feats available to you in terms of offense, getting a nice defensive feat is great too, and some of the damage feats like power attack are good when you can overcome their negatives. As long as you remember HIT, CRIT ATTACKS.

For spell casters you wanna look at what they're already good at and just pick everything that powers up what they're good at. For example, Nenio is a wizard you get. She specializes in illusion magic. If you search 'Illusion' you will find feats like specializations and such to power them up. Also spell penetration. You can also take meta magic feats. The two best ones are the Selective (makes it only hit bad guys) and Heighten (lets you basically make a spell higher level so it it is stronger). Get those and just pick shit related to what they do. It looks overwhelming, but just think about what actually makes your spells stronger. Ignore all the weird dumb bullshit.

>>631663414
You merge your class spellbook (which goes up to level 20) with your mythic level, to max of 30. So any spells that scale based on your spell level will be doing 10 extra levels of damage. You also gain access to certain spells faster.

>>631663414
Only angel and lich can do it and only with certain classes, basically means you get spells earlier and you cast them at a higher level, if you go a mythic path without merging you'd get the same spells eventually but the spell level will be lower

>>631663414
All mythics have a spellbook.
Angel and Lich have lv9 spellbooks progressing.
Merging (angel with full divine, lich with full arcane) means:
a) Your mythic level gets assed to your caste level (maximum 30 instead of 20)
b) The mythic spells are offered/unlocked as you progress the class, not in a sperate spellbook.
c) If you are a PREPARED caster, not spontaneous, you unlock spells faster

1) It's mostly combat.

5) It's balanced by cheeselords.
Now there's no "gotcha" chokepoint where if you don't have a certain skill you're fucked, and you'll know if your build sucks at the first "big" dungeon when your character gets about the point where you can call it a build, but it's definitely flawed.

Name three.

>>631666227
>Yi Sang
Either accidental gourmet or something that puts Dr. Pepper to shame with ambiguous ingredients
>Faust
Soulless, quick, and filling. The hallmarks of a scientist cooking for themselves
>Don Quixote
Uses ingredients that makes the flavors she likes rather than ones that compliment the dish
>Ryoushu
Not safe for human consumption. Looks very artistic if you're the type to think splayed intestines have more artistic merit than anything in the Lourve
>Meursault
Follows a recipe to the letter, turns out pretty good.
>Hong Lu
Hasn't the first idea how to cook. Has many wonderful ideas for dishes but not the ability to make them a reality.
>Heathcliff
Knows how to cook, but fucks up the recipe on purpose. Everything he does cook is charred black.
>Ishmael
Very salty, not particularly nutritious, but very filling.
>Rodion
Only knows how to cook with cheap ingredients, but can make some pretty good food with it.
>Sinclair
Tries to recreate his mother's cooking, but doesn't manage to make it with love.
>Outis
Bland. Nutritious. Compact. If you ever wondered what it was like to have an entire day's food on the end of a fork, Outis will show you.
>Gregor
More military food, but cheaper and more depressing. Has a certain phobia of recipes with apples for some reason.
>Vergilius
The best chef of the bunch. Refuses to cook anything until Ryoshu tried to feed Charon. Only makes enough for the two of them though.

>>631660772
Because the names are different in the context of different languages. In Japanese Leur sounds like "Dragon" (RYUru) and "Ruler".
In English they wanted to keep his name sounding like a king, so they gave him a name with "Lear", which is a name commonly asociated with kings.

In japanese "Misutira" is syllabic anagram of "Tiramisu" (tira misu, misu tira) that sounds girly and cutesy when she pronounces her name. In English, however, the name sounds to close to Mystical and would give her name and character an almost complete opposite interpretation of her intended, "sweet" personality.
Instead in English they gave her a name that associates her with earth, which is consistent with her thematics in combat and Solm as a nation. In my opinion they could have tried another allusion to Tiramisu, but Rhajat and Caeldori are awful names so I'd rather them not.

Skill gems are fine and its a great concept for RPGs. Isaac and Roguelikes in general basically do the concept pretty well. Give your skills modifiers that uniquely change their properties that can allow for thousands of potential synergies and permutations. It makes games very re-playable.
The needing links and socket colors etc is a balance and online cost thing and are fucking dumb (they're removing that in 2 so it seems like they realize this themselves). I also agree with the over leveling thing, that's rare in the game, it's mainly for things like mana management, or in rare instances, for attack speed timing in rarer instances working with more modern CoC builds (Cospri's etc). Some builds WANT high cost mana spells, some don't and depend on very small mana costs and mana leech to push as much power out of the build as possible, but difficulty increases over the time without substantial player buffs (big part of what everyone in the thread is complaining about, their refusal to buff player power/fun) have made that less of a minmax thing and more of a requirement. But I agree it's a dumb system and you should just be able to freely go up and down from levels of a gem once you've leveled too it and its just another stupid currency sink because they're desperate for playtime and think that the best way for long player retention is to tax player time instead of making it more enjoyable/easy to level up, and too milk whales they need to limit the risk of players maxing a build, getting bored and leaving till next league not buying points. It's all greed, and the devs have openly stated this as their reasoning before.

GGG became waaaay too butthurt so they swapped them. GGG has to be the smartest guys in the room. They immediately changed a recipe that allowed you to get wisdom scrolls for perandus coins. Few thousand perandus coins drop, trade them in for wizzys. Bam, done. GGG said fuck that.

One of GGG's favorite items has been the timeless jewels from Legions. They are given random numbers with stats that can only be seen if they are slotted in your tree. thread:
It's not that complicated
>characters will have all their transformations
>It should have all the movie villains
>It should have giant characters (Oozaru, Pilaf Machine, ect..)
>It's okay to have some GT and Super representation but the priority should be focused on classic Z since that's what most people give a shit about
>No CaC shit
>No Heroes content
>No fanfiction what-if fusion trash characters
>If they add anything from the current manga it should be 3 characters maximum (and should be reserved for DLC)
>It has to have a bigger starting roster than Tenkaichi 1 (64 characters)
>It has to have a bigger starting roster than Raging Blast 1 (73 characters)
>and it sure as fuck will have a bigger starting roster than Xenoverse 1 (45 characters without counting transformations)
I don't think a 100 minimum character roster is that crazy given the essentials they will have to add, the fact it's a sequel to an already established franchise where everyone has huge expectations, and the fact we don't even know how long they've been working on this game. We don't even know for a fact if they could have possibly reused character models from previous games like Xenoverse 2 but obviously changed them given the current aesthetic. I don't think it's out of the realm of possibility that this could be the most ambitious Dragon Ball game ever made considering the fact it's easily the one people have been looking forward to the most. I think no matter what it will disappoint some people but I don't think they would even attempt to make a new Tenkaichi if they didn't plan on going all out. Why would they make something they know would fail miserably and lose money given the fandom they're focusing on? I'm usually pessimistic but I think it's going to be something special.

>>631629873
In brief, Kellhus is from a hyper-rational order of warrior-monks known as the Dunyain. He's initially sent out on a mission to assassinate his father, but it turns out that there's a complex plan to defeat this group of rapist wizards (and some aliens) called the Unholy Consult, who want to cull the human population so they can escape damnation. When the human population is below a hundred thousand, there's not enough consciousness to sustain hell: Everyone who dies just goes to oblivion instead.
Kellhus, over the course of twenty years, raises an enormous army to take the fight to the Unholy Consult. He makes it all the way there, to find out that the Unholy Consult has subsumed the Dunyain. Being hyper-rationalists, the Dunyain see that they have no reason NOT to side with the Consult (as they're all damned to Hell anyway.)
Kellhus, expecting this confrontation, has ensured he's possessed by a demon so he can nuke them. Unfortunately, they outplay him: Kellhus' crazy son (who is like, twelve) distracts him at a crucial moment and Kellhus is instantly turned to salt, killing him.
Kellhus' son is shoved into a sacrophagus and possessed by the No-God, an AI that is both a powerful weapon and has the metaphysical ability to ensure that no living children are born.
Outside, Kellhus' army starts celebrating just in time to take the No-God's manifestation (a black whirlwind) right in the fucking face.
Then millions of Orcs come pouring out of Mordor, to rape and kill everyone. Every surviving member of the cast flees screaming into the night, pursued by the Crossed.
And that's where we leave off.
Tell me, Poyas: <s>Does it trouble you?</s>

>>631631389
It is not worse than Malazan. Malazan is just incompetently written, with shitfuck characterization (I sure do love illiterate soldiers ruminate on horrors of war in the vein of XXI century intellectuals), nonsensical worldbuilding (an empire which is literally in its second generation being treated as if existed for many centuries, with nobility established long enough to grow soft and corrupt, etc) and a whole of nothing happening. Malazan is praised for having a complicated plot unfolding over a lot of pages, with things coming together books later. But every second 1000-chapters cultivation novel has a comparably complicated plot. And unlike Malazan chink writers make sure that something happens in every chapter.

Now Second Apocalypes is only superfiically similar to Malazan in that it is (far more) grimdark. Unlike Malazan, it is largely competently written. And it has non-banal themes that the author wishes to express - I'm saying that as a person who completely disagrees with Bakker's opinion on pretty much everything. However, it's yet to be seen if Bakker is actually competent enough to write himself out of the corner he wrote himself into by following through on his thematic setup, and have a conclusion different from "actually the world is shit and deserves destruction" without major asspulls.

>>631609723
Deal More Damage for your damage dealers like Hikari, Osvald, and Castti. BP Boost is also good, especially paired with A Step Ahead to have 3 BP in the first non Step Ahead round. Full Power is good for a lot of characters. Ochette or Hikari with FP, BP Boost, and A Step Ahead can pretty much wipe out random encounters in an instant. Agnea is good with those paired with Merchant for Arrow of Fortune spam to get extra JP. Getting Vigorous Vigor is also cheap as hell and can sustain you while you travel before you get to those capstone abilities.

For Ochette I aimed for multi hitting attacks and upgraded them to their All versions when I came across them. If you go get a Revenant early it can carry you through pretty much any random encounter with the Step Ahead and BP Boost combo. Chubby Caits throw out a slew of buffs and Octo Kings hit enemies with debuffs so they're pretty solid, especially with her 2nd EX skills. Battle Tested Shark is fucking bonkers, you can get it in the ocean during the day after you fight it as a boss. You can get Scourge of the Seas the same way just during the night. Shark hits all enemies with a dagger hit and restores your party's HP, SP, and gives 1 BP. Scourge slams the fuck out of one enemy and does a guaranteed 6 shield break. Both are once per battle but her EX skill allows you to circumvent that restriction.

Well. Only ever so slightly. But the passage that Shirlutto reads in his study of humans through that history book. Is about the tragedy of the prince and princess of opposing kingdoms who end up fleeing and disappearing together.
Now the book has no mention of Lostseed, but it's pretty evident by how many times the beginning of that very passage is repeated verbatim throughout the game, that it is indeed the one and the same story. The story that ended up culminating in the prince and princess establishing Lostseed with their remaining retainers. And then we learn in Throné's story how she is related to that very story by blood.

That's all really. Shirlutto's reading of the passage doesn't really elaborate on anything. I just realised that it was connected, and did not expect it to be.

>>631641125
There's no flow in the sequence of attacks. He's above head level for that first kick, goes down to do an uppercut, goes down AGAIN for a close body blow, and then kicks Freezy away. It is objectively bad.

It COULD have been so much more coherent just by reorganizing the four panels.
Bodyblow first, implies Gohan goes center of mass, the impact tilts Frieza's head forward.
That sets up the uppercut, both elevating Gohan and putting his right leg behind him.
Naturally, the sweeping kick with his right foot is set up to swat Frieza's head.

I think the important thing to point out here is that the writer behind the game is a lot less smart than she thinks she is. She presents this as a profound ethical quandary... But it's not. The fireflies are butchers and grifters who ripped off Joel and resorted to a lethal surgical procedure without a legitimate justification.. and it needed to end the way it did because the game needed to end with a climactic setpiece because, well, it was a video game.

Lisa the Painful presented a similar moral quandary with better writing. The Rando army kidnapped Buddy because she was the last female in the world and they wanted to keep her protected from rapists until she was ready to have children but Brad wanted to get her back because she was his adopted daughter and his desire to keep her safe and happy stemmed from his failure to protect his little sister, Lisa, from her father who would abuse, neglect, and isolate her, and even rape her. Each side of this conflict was sympathetic and had understandable motives and it was ambiguous which one wad truly right in the end, as opposed to Last of Us, where there's a clear good guy and bad guy when that wasn't the intention in the first place.

I mean, the TV series made a straight adaptation of the video game but it's a TV show so it doesn't have to end like a video game setpiece. They could have re-written it as a dialogue-driven dramatic denouement that comes to a violent head.
